title: Yasuní-ITT 'Leave Oil Underground' Initiative
summary: Ecuador proposed leaving 846 million barrels of oil underground in Yasuní National Park in exchange for US$3.6 billion in international compensation. The initiative raised only US$13.3 million and was abandoned in 2013, representing an innovative but ultimately failed experiment in payments for ecosystem services.

keyData.label: Biodiversity
keyData.value: One of Earth's most biodiverse areas

content:
## Background

Yasuní National Park, located in the Ecuadorian Amazon, is one of the most biodiverse places on Earth. A single hectare of Yasuní forest contains more tree species than are native to all of North America. The park is also home to the Tagaeri and Taromenane, two of the last uncontacted indigenous groups in the world, living in voluntary isolation within the Zona Intangible declared by the Ecuadorian government in 1999.

Beneath this ecological treasure lies the Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) oil block, containing an estimated 846 million barrels of heavy crude oil—approximately 20% of Ecuador's known reserves. The prospect of drilling in Yasuní posed a stark tradeoff between economic development and environmental conservation in a country where oil revenues constituted roughly one-third of government income.

## The Intervention

In 2007, President Rafael Correa proposed an unprecedented initiative: Ecuador would permanently forgo exploiting the ITT oil fields if the international community would contribute US$3.6 billion over 13 years—representing approximately half the expected revenues from extraction. The proposal was grounded in the principle of co-responsibility, arguing that protecting global public goods like biodiversity and climate stability required shared financial commitment.

The initiative was formalized through a trust fund administered by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). Contributing countries would receive Yasuní Guarantee Certificates (CGYs)—tradeable instruments redeemable if Ecuador reneged on its commitment. The proposal gained significant international attention and was presented at multiple UN General Assembly sessions.

The theoretical foundation drew on the concept of payments for ecosystem services (PES), but at an unprecedented sovereign scale. As Larrea and Warnars (2009) outlined, the avoided emissions of approximately 407 million metric tons of CO2 provided a climate rationale, while biodiversity preservation and indigenous rights added further justification.

## Results & Evidence

Despite extensive diplomatic effort, the initiative failed to mobilize significant funding. By the time President Correa officially terminated the initiative on August 15, 2013, only US$13.3 million had been deposited in the UNDP trust fund, with an additional US$116 million in pledges. Germany had initially pledged $50 million annually but later withdrew, citing concerns about governance and credibility.

Finer et al. (2009), writing in *Science*, provided a detailed analysis of the ecological stakes, documenting that oil development in Yasuní would require building roads into pristine forest, which research consistently showed leads to colonization, deforestation, and biodiversity loss. They argued the initiative represented a novel mechanism for internalizing environmental externalities.

Following the initiative's abandonment, the government approved drilling in the ITT block. In 2023, Ecuadorians voted in a national referendum to halt oil extraction in Yasuní, though implementation of the referendum results has faced legal and logistical challenges.

Researchers have debated why the initiative failed. Vallejo et al. (2015) identified several factors: free-rider problems among potential donor nations, skepticism about Ecuador's long-term commitment, the lack of a binding international framework for such arrangements, and the global financial crisis that constrained donor budgets during the initiative's critical early years.

## Challenges & Criticisms

The Yasuní-ITT initiative faced fundamental design challenges. The free-rider problem was severe: any individual country's contribution would benefit all nations through climate and biodiversity protection, creating incentives to let others pay. Without a binding international mechanism, voluntary contributions were insufficient.

Credibility was another significant concern. Potential donors questioned whether Ecuador would truly forgo extraction permanently. The initiative's dependence on a single political leader's commitment—and Correa's own ambivalent statements about a "Plan B" of drilling—undermined confidence.

Critics from both sides challenged the proposal. Environmental groups argued that making conservation contingent on payment set a dangerous precedent, essentially allowing countries to hold ecosystems hostage. Development advocates countered that asking a middle-income country to forgo billions in revenues without adequate compensation was unrealistic.

The initiative also raised sovereignty questions about who should bear the costs of preserving global commons.

## Key Lessons

- Innovative PES concepts at the sovereign level face enormous collective action and free-rider problems without binding international frameworks
- The credibility of long-term commitments by political leaders is insufficient collateral for large-scale international conservation finance
- The tension between resource-dependent development and environmental conservation requires institutional solutions beyond voluntary arrangements
- Domestic democratic mechanisms (like Ecuador's 2023 referendum) may ultimately prove more effective than international negotiation for conservation decisions
- The initiative's conceptual legacy influenced subsequent debates about fossil fuel supply-side climate policies
